Of all foreign languages even the Khmer language appears to be distantly related to the Eurasian superfamilies:

first-person Pronouns ego/moin â‡” kÊ°É²om â‹ ğ“¡ğ“ˆ–ğ“…±

It belongs to the Eurasian superfamilies which use m,w,n,g for first person consonants, but not say b,l,r,t (at least not in a leading position). Like "mama" it might be anatomically prewired though.

Connecting these distant languages seems a bit far-fetched but the Turbino phenomenon and the rapid extension of the Copper Revolution, as well as millennia of proto-indo-european neighborhood give scenarios in which some diffusion or even common roots of IE and Khmer are plausible. Suddenly it might not be a coincidence when the biggest city on Earth in the Middle Ages was called Ankor Wat â‡” ğ“‹¹ğ“Š–kurğŸŒ¢.
Kor is without a doubt the most recognisable international name for cities.
